objective.answer: The primary objective of the paper is to explore the potential of using large language models (LLMs) to aid in the design of soft modular robots, reducing the reliance on extensive trial-and-error experiments typically needed to achieve robot designs that meet specific structural or task requirements.
objective.evidence: In this paper, we further explore the potential of using LLMs to aid in the design of soft modular robots, taking into account both user instructions and physical laws, to reduce the reliance on extensive trial-and-error experiments typically needed to achieve robot designs that meet specific structural or task requirements.

knowledge_gap.answer: The paper addresses the gap in the use of large language models for designing soft modular robots, which has not been explored before.
knowledge_gap.evidence: To our knowledge, none of the modular robot design frameworks have utilized large language models (LLMs), and we are particularly interested in exploring the potential and capabilities of LLMs for this purpose.

answer: The use of large language models (LLMs) for designing soft modular robots is novel.
The introduction of a simulation tool to provide feedback to the generative model, allowing for iterative improvements without requiring extensive human annotations, is a novel approach.
The development of five evaluation metrics to assess the quality of robot designs from multiple angles is a new contribution.
evidence: To our knowledge, none of the modular robot design frameworks have utilized large language models (LLMs), and we are particularly interested in exploring the potential and capabilities of LLMs for this purpose.

To simplify, rather than conducting real-world experiments to assess design quality, we utilize a simulation tool to provide feedback to the generative model, allowing for iterative improvements without requiring extensive human annotations.

Furthermore, we introduce five evaluation metrics to assess the quality of robot designs from multiple angles including task completion and adherence to instructions, supporting an automatic evaluation process.

steps.step: Formulate the robot design process as a sequence generation task using LLMs.
steps.input: Natural language instructions and physical laws.
steps.evidence: Specifically, we formulate the robot design process as a sequence generation task and find that LLMs are able to capture key requirements expressed in natural language and reflect them in the construction sequences of robots.

steps.step: Utilize a simulation tool to provide feedback to the generative model.
steps.input: Simulation tool and generated robot designs.
steps.evidence: To simplify, rather than conducting real-world experiments to assess design quality, we utilize a simulation tool to provide feedback to the generative model, allowing for iterative improvements without requiring extensive human annotations.

steps.step: Introduce and apply five evaluation metrics to assess robot designs.
steps.output: Evaluation results based on task completion and adherence to instructions.

limitations.name: Slow Cooling Time of SMAs
limitations.description: The slow cooling time of the Shape Memory Alloy (SMA) coils restricts the locomotion speed of the robot.
limitations.evidence: One limitation of our current system is the slow cooling time of the Shape Memory Alloy (SMA) coils, which restricts the locomotion speed of the robot.

limitations.name: Simulation Discrepancies
limitations.description: Discrepancies exist between the real and simulated robots, affecting the alignment of simulation with real-world performance.
limitations.evidence: Discrepancies exist between the real and simulated robots: real-world connections have four nodes on the connecting line, while the simulation, limited by DiffTaichi, has only two.
